content.description:
Start up

Scorcher

, clip a piton and move right up a ramp using increasingly poor holds and feet.  Once the ramp peters out, clip a modern bolt, and execute a very technical compression crux involving horrible feet, and long reaches that gets you to slopey ledge.  The last and hardest crux has a more traditional feel.  Clip another piton, and lieback/jam up a left leaning seam to the top.

Although there is fixed gear, this feels like kind of a serious lead due to the questionable nature of the old pitons.

This felt more like 12+ to me.
content.protection: 3 quickdraws. There is no anchor at the top.
content.location:
This is to the right of

Scorcher

.

content.description: Thin slab climbing past the two bolts makes up the crux.
content.location: This is on the far right side of the rock.

content.description:
The right side of the South face of the Canyon Block is split by a fairly pleasant zigzagging hand/finger crack.

Scramble into a dihedral at the base of the crack, and move up and right into the crux, stemming and balancing between two widely spaced cracks.  Eventually, the difficulties end, and larger holds give way to the top.
content.protection: Small to midsized cams, some long runners to reduce rope drag, and some gear to set up an anchor. A 50 meter rope will easily get you back to the ground.
content.location: The crack is on the right side of the South face.

content.description: This is the obvious, left-leaning, hand crack in the middle of the Southwest side of the Canyon Block.  The short crux is about 3/4 of the way up, and starts once you leave the good feet and commit to the crack.  It has good gear, good rock, and nice moves, and topping out is fun.
content.protection: Bring a couple of #1-3 sized Camalots and some blue to red sized Metolius cams.  You may need additional cams, some locking biners, and webbing to set up a natural anchor on a tree or some of the cracks found at the top of the block.  A 50 meter rope will easily get you back to the ground.
content.location: This route starts right of a large, right-facing dihedral on good holds that lead to an obvious, hand crack in the middle of the Southwest side of the block.  To retrieve gear, the top is easily accessed by the North side.

climbs.name: Rude Boy
climbs.fa: Mark Rolofson with Dan McQuade, November, 1986; first lead, Bob Horan?

content.description:
The crux is gaining a thin crack about 30 feet up, a hard mantle tries to keep you from the crack.

Really good route.
content.protection: Thin gear to a gray camalot.
content.location: Where the rock bends to the east. The obvious corner/crack.

content.description:
The route was climbed as a head-point. It starts to the right of

Blues of Allah

on a small chunk of pretty, lichen-splattered rock. It climbs up into an obvious little seam, which takes small RPs that will protect the crux. Hard climbing follows the fading seam up and left until the route meets the vertical crack on

Blues of Allah

. Easier climbing leads to the top-out. The crux on the route is protected (the fall on small gear has been taken), but the climbing above is not.
content.protection:
There is a one-bolt anchor and a solid tree on top of the block that can easily be accessed walking around right.

A variety of small RPs will allow you to build a little nest in the seam down low. This protects the hard climbing on both Palestine and

Israel

. At the top of Palestine, a yellow Alien-sized cam fits in the vertical seam and offers protection for the upper climbing and the top out.

An anchor can be built at the base (in the crack down right) in order to weight RPs in the correct direction in case the climber falls in the crux. We used a couple bigger cams and some cord.
content.location: The route is located on the Milk Dud, or Canyon Block on the right side of the block. It is a vertical face with bolted lines on both the far left and far right.

content.description:
This route is the sister to

Palestine

and was also climbed as a head-point. It shares a start with

Palestine

and the same initial protection (small RPs in the seam). Israel then trends right, climbing hard slab moves (crux, protected) until you reach a rail. Traverse left along the obvious hand rail until it abruptly ends. A few unprotected 5.11 moves straight up find you at a good stance where a cam can be placed to protect the top-out. The top moves offer an exciting mental crux.
content.protection:
One-bolt anchor and tree are easily reached walking around right to set up a top rope. Small RPs in low seam protect the crux climbing. A black mastercam-sized piece up top protects the top out.

An anchor can be built at the base (in the crack down right) in order to weight RPs in the correct direction in case the climber falls in the crux. We used a couple bigger cams and some cord.
content.location:
This is on the right side of the Canyon Block, just to the left of

Tricks Are for Kids

and right of

Palestine

.

climbs.name: Damaged Goods
climbs.fa: Skip Guerin TR., Rolofson, Horan Lead

content.description:
This would be a fairly ballsy lead. Just left of

Rude Boy

on the SW arete. Scramble up on to some blocks and climb a left angling seam up left to a jug and the arete proper. Two mank pins are your first pro. You may be able to get something in before but the pro would probobly take up your handhold. Athletic and powerful climbing the rest of the way up a thin crack. Really cool.
content.protection: RPs and TCUs. A couple of extra draws for pins.
content.location:
This is just left of

Rude Boy

on the SW arete.

content.description:
Left of

Tricks Are For Kids

is a left-leaning seam that quickly disappears into blankness. Very difficult but semi-safe climbing leads well above the last protection to a 5.11X finish. A number of years ago I worked out the moves and the protection which is small but solid in the seam but non-existent after the crux.

I am writing this route/project up to encourage anyone who is looking for a genuinely difficult, headpoint-style route in the Boulder area. I also want to discourage anyone from bolting this line as a top-rope is easily set up. This project will be quite difficult and fairly dangerous to lead. I think this is a great example of the kind of pitch that should not have bolts added.
content.protection: Small stoppers, Aliens--best to work out the gear on rappel.
content.location:
This is between

Blues for Allah

and

Tricks are for Kids

.

content.description: This is a sport pitch up the left side of the vertical face. This route is all about slab climbing and is significantly harder if you are shorter. It has really beautiful rock with tiny holds and technical climbing. The crux(es) are in the middle of the route and are protected by bolts. Easier climbing up high is protected by a cam. The route tops out on this little chunk of really quality BC rock.
content.protection: A stopper (#4 or #5) protects the climbing to the first bolt. Two bolts. You can place a yellow Alien-sized piece in the vertical crack up high. There is a one bolt anchor and tree on top (the route tops out).
content.location: Look for the obvious vertical face on the right side of Canyon Block. Blues for Allah is the obvious, bolted line on the left side of this face.
